Minutes of the Annual Meeting of the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed
Memorial Association held at Washington, D. C., November 20, 1944.

The Board of Managers met in the Board Room American Security and Trust Company,
15th Street and Pennsulvania Avenue, Northwest, at 10:15 A.M. and was called to order
by its Vice President, Majore General M. W. Ireland.

Present: Maj. Gen. M. W. Ireland, Brig. Gen. F. R. Keefer, Mr. Gilbert Grosvenor,
Brig. Gen. A. G. Love, Mr. Hans W. Ireland and Col. J. F. Siler.

Absent: Brig. Gen. J. R. Kean (illness), Maj. Gen. C. R. Reynolds, Rear Admiral E. R.
Stitt, Dr. L. O. Howard and Lt. Col. Julian M. Cabell.

As the minutes of the last meeting had been mailed to each member of the Board,
a motion was made, seconded and carried that the reading of the minutes be omitted and
that they be approved as written.

The Treasurer presented his annual report showing in summary comparative income
and disbursements for the current and past fiscal years and the market value of the
capital investments of the Memorial Fund as of October 31, 1943 and October 31, 1944,
as follows:

div1.p: The report of the Treasurer was approved.

The following officers were elected for the forthcoming year:
President Brig. Gen. Jefferson R. Kean
Vice President Major Gen. M. W. Ireland
Secretary Colonel Joseph F. Siler
Treasurer Mr. Hans W. Ireland

General Love called attention to the fact that there had recently been published
“Memoirs of Walter Reed - the Yellow Fever Episode”, by Brig. Gen. Albert E. Truby,
U. S. Army, Retired, which contributed materially to existing knowledge of the
experiments conducted by Walter Reed and his coworkers in demonstrating so quickly
and so conclusively the method of transmission of yellow fever. It was resolved that
the Board express to Gen. Truby its appreciation of his material contribution to the
existing literature on Walter Reed. The following letter of appreciation prepared by
Gen. Love was ssnt to Gen. Truby:

Washington
21 November 1944

Brigadier General Albert E. Truby,
145 Laurel Street,
San Francisco, California.
My dear General Truby:

The Walter Reed Memorial Association at its annual meeting at 10 A.M. November
20, 1944, by unanimous vote, directed me to express to you the sincere appreciation
of the Association for your outstanding contribution to the Walter Reed literature
by your “Memoirs of Walter Reed -- the Yellow Fever Episode.”

The Association appreciates that it is extremely fortunate that you kept such
accurate and timely records of your observations, and further that after many busy
years of active military service you took advantage of the leisure afforded by your
retirement to record and transmit, in a thorough way to your contemporaries and to
posterity, so accurately and impartially, your observations of the dramatic events
that have since affected so greatly the health and economic development of large
sections of this hemisphere.

The work of Walter Reed and his associates, as recorded so effectively by you,
will continue to be a model for such research and an inspiration to scientists.

The Association wishes me to express to you, not only its gratitude for this
work, but its sincere regards and best wishes.

Cordially,
JEFFERSON R. KEAN
Brigadier General, U. S. A., Retired
President, W.R.M.A.

J. F. SILER
Colonel, U.S.A., Retired
Secretary, W.R.M.A.

Colonel Siler stated that he thought the Board of Managers of the Walter Reed
Memorial Association, as now constituted, should make of record an expression of their
opinion as to the manner in which the work of Walter Reed should be perpetuated
through the establishment, eventually, of a permanent memorial. This for the reason
that some of the present members were his friends or close friends and others were
contemporaries who knew him and had an intimate knowledge of his yellow fever research
work and, thus, are best qualified to express an opinion in consonance with present
day conceptions of memorials as to the form the permanent memorial should take, whether
a “living” memorial in the form of a Research Fund the income from which could be
used for research or the use of the capital fund for the purchase and installation of
a monument to Walter Reed in Washington, D.C.

In finally determining the type of permanent memorial to be established, the
Board of Managers must of necessity take into consideration information available in
the minutes of meetings of the original icorporators, minutes of the meetings of
their successors and information incorporated in the Articles of Incorporation. All
minutes have been reviewed and pertinent extracts from the minutes and Articles of
Incorporation follow:

item.p:
1) From the minutes of the meeting of the General Committee held at Bar Harbor, Maine,
August 15, 1903: (Vol. 1, p.2) (Vol. 1, p.4)

“Resolved, That this meeting express its approbation of the following sug-
gestions, and commend them to the concurrence of all other committees interested
in a memorial to Major Walter Reed:
1. That an effort be made to raise a fund of $25,000 or more.
2. 2. That the invome thereof shall be paid to Mrs. Reed during her lifetime
and to her daughter (if she survives her mother) during her lifetime.
3. After both deaths the principal shall be devoted to the erection of a
suitable memorial to Major Reed in the City of Washington, or to the establish-
ment of a fund for the promotion of research in the field to which he was de-
voted. The decision between these projects and the carrying out of the plan
which may be adopted shall be left absolutely to the committee below designated.”
“The sentiment of the persons present, afterwards confirmed by conversation,
appeared to be in favor of placing in Washington a sculptured monument commemor-
ating Major Reed, with a well-considered inscription which should set forth his
great contribution to the welfare of mankind.”

2) From the minutes of a meeting of the committee designated by the American Associ-
ation for the Advancement of Science, held at Philadelphia: (Vol. 1, p.5)
"The following motions were made and carried:

“That a memorial of an enduring and visible character be erected in the City
of Washington. D.C., at a point to be later selected, to Major Reed.”

list.item:
3) From the Certificate of Incorporation: (Vol. 1, p.7)
"FIRST. The name of the association shall be “The Walter Reed Memorial Associ-
ation”; and the objects for which it is formed are to commemorate by a suitable
memorial the eminent scientific and public services of the late Major Walter
Reed, Surgeon, U. S. Army, and to raise funds for that object; also to assist,
if necessary, with the income of such fund the wife and daughter of said Walter
Reed.
"SECOND. The existence of said association shall be until the objects for which
it is organized have been completed and terminated.
"THIRD. The capital of the Association shall consist of such funds as may be
raised for the purposes above named.
"FOURTH. The affairs of said Association shall be managed for the first year
by Surgeon General R. M. O'Reilly, U.S. Army; Gen. George M. Sternberg, U.S.A.;
Retired; Major J. R. Kean, U.S.A.; President D. C. Gilman; Dr. F. S. Nash, U.S.A.;
Mr. A. G. Bell; Mr. W. A. Gordon; Gen. Calvin DeWitt, U.S.A., Retired; Dr. J.
Carroll, U.S.A.; Dr. W. D. MCCaw, U.S.A.; and Dr. A.F.A. King, who shall
-3-
organize for the carrying out of the purposes of the Association. After the first
year the affairs shall be conducted by such officers as the Association shall elect.”

item.p:
4) From a fund solicitation letter written by Gen. Sternberg for distribution to the
Medical profession which was approved for distribution by the Executive Committee,
Board of Managers, at its meeting in Washington, May 9, 1904: (Vol., p. 18)

“ - - - It is thought that at least $25,000 should be raised and it is probably
that the exact character of the Memorial will not be determined until a con-
siderable portion of this amount is in the hands of the Treasurer.”
5) From the by-laws of the Walter Reed Memorial Association. (Vol.1, p.37)

“The objects of the Association are to commemorate by a suitable memorial
the eminent scientific and public services of the late Major Walter Reed, Sur-
geon, U. S. Army, and to raise funds for that object; also to assist, if necessary,
with the income of such fund the wife and daughter of Major Reed.”

6) From the minutes of a meeting of the Executive Committee held in Washington, D.C.,
December 20, 1904: (Vol. 1, p.47)

“Dr. Kean stated he had had an interview with Mrs. Walter Reed, who stated
she would prefer having an income of the fund paid to her, and in the event of
her death, provision made for their daughter.

div1.p:
“Dr. A. F. A. King offered the following: “RESOLVED. That when the sum
of $25,000 is received, the net income of the fund shall be paid over to Mrs.
Walter Reed during her lifetime,” which was seconded by Mr. Bell and carried.”

The quotations from minutes of meetings, quoted above, indicate quite clearly that
it was the intent that the annual income from the fund should be paid to Mrs. Walter
Reed during her lifetime and thereafter to her daughter and that no steps should be
taken to establish a permanent memorial until after the deaths of the two above-
mentioned beneficiaries.

Extracts from minutes of meetings and other data quoted above indicate that no
definite steps have ever been taken specifying the type of permanent memorial that
should be established, though the data do indicate that it was the general impression,
when the funds were being raised, that the memorial would be in the form of a statue
erected in Washington. However, at the initial organizational meeting at Bar Harbor
in August, 1903 a Resolution adopted indicated that it was the intent of the committee
that the fund to be raised would be devoted to the erection of a suitable memorial to
Walter Reed in Washington or to the establishment of a fund for the promotion of re-
search, the decision between the two projects to be made at a later date by the com-
mittee.

In April, 1904 the Walter Reed Memorial was incorporated in the District of Colum-
bia and the Certificate of Incorporation contains no reference as to the form of perman-
ent memorial to be established other than that one of the objects of the Association is
to “commemorate by a suitable memorial the eminent scientific and public services of
the late Major Walter Reed.” There also appears in the minutes of a meeting of the
-4-
Executive Committee on May 9, 1904 the following statement contained in a fund-raising
letter to the medical profession, the distribution of which was approved by the Exec-
utive Committee: “It is thought that at least $25,000. should be raised and it is pro-
bable that the exact character of the Memorial will not be determined until a consid-
erable portion of this amount is in the hands of the Treasurer.” No further references
to this matter appear in the minutes of subsequent meetings of the Executive Committee
or Board of Managers of the Association orther than approved statements appearing in
letters soliciting funds, already referred to.

It is evident that the Board of Managers of the Association as successor to the
original organizing committee eventually will be charged with the responsibility of
determining the exact form of memorial to be established.

It was felt by Col. Siler that the facts just reviewed indicated that the Board
of Managers could adopt one of two plans for a permanent memorial -- a “Living” me-
morial in the form of a Memorial Fund, the income of which would be devoted to sci-
entific research or a statue of Walter Reed to be erected in Washington. He had dis-
cussed the matter with Gen. Ireland, Gen. Kean and Mr. Ireland and they felt as he did
that the fund should be held intact and the annual income used for the prosecution of
suitable research. Gen. Kean felt that as Major Reed had graduated in medicine from
the University of Virginia it would be well to have the income from the fund used by
the Medical Department of the University of Virginia for research work.

The matter was discussed generally at the meeting and it was the unanimous opinion
of all the members present that the form of memorial should be use of the income from
the fund for scientific research rather than the expenditure of the principal for the
erection of a visible monument.

There being no further business to come before the meeting, it adjourned to meet
at the call of the President.

J. F. SILER
Colonel, U. S. Army, Retired
Secretary
